Fields.DialogueText: Everyone! Get to your stations!
@BATTLE
Not bad, Captain. You fight with a strong warrior spirit. However...
However?
Our overall approach puts too much emphasis on protecting civilian infrastructure. Instead of hunting the enemy to ground, we just lurk in place.

Fields.MenuText: Are you questioning our orders?
We got the job done, didn't we?
What would you have done?

Fields.DialogueText: Simply making an observation.
Done and done well are two different things, Captain.
For a start, choose a port to use as bait. Clear its defenses, wait for local Morganas to swarm, and then sweep in and gut them while they're trapped between us and shore. They're not very smart.
You must be bold. In battle there is no room for mercy.

Fields.MenuText: We have to be better than our enemies.
It's a fair point. The enemy only respects power.
Sometimes the strongest tactic is to hold back.

Fields.DialogueText: Being pointlessly sentimental in war isn't "better." Determination is what matters.
Spoken like a true warrior, Captain.
You have an interesting philosophy, Captain.
I pray that our enemies lack such confidence.
On that we can agree...
You summoned me, Captain?
We've received word of a civilian vessel in the vicinity, apparently without working engines. Morganas are en route to intercept.
And?
And we're going to rescue them before the enemy arrives.
That's our first priority, Captain? Really?

Fields.MenuText: We have our orders.
Saving lives is always the first priority.
You'll notice I didn't say we weren't going to crush the enemy as well.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, orders are orders. Even unwise ones.
The enemy will exploit our compassion, Captain.
I like how you think, Captain.
Prepare for battle. And ready a rescue party.
Do not forget. Defeating the enemy must always come first.
@BATTLE
Captain, I'm bored.
Ready for another battle so soon?
Always. Warriors exist only for the fight.

Fields.MenuText: There's more to life than fighting.
Hopefully we'll see our next battle soon.
Is there anything you enjoy besides fighting?

Fields.DialogueText: Life itself is a fight. There is nothing else.
I cannot wait for us to test ourselves in battle again.
I have but one thing...
Do you enjoy music, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: Never touch the stuff.
Of course.
Only when there's time.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, maybe you will enjoy this anyway.
Otlichno. Then you should enjoy this.
We must fill the time between battle somehow.
Is that a bandura you have there?
It is. I'll... play you a short tune.
*BOOM*
Hmm... we're under attack.
Your concert will have to wait.
In my mind, battle is always a welcome interruption.
@BATTLE
Captain. I take it you've spotted the enemy?
I have. I don't suppose I need to ask if you're ready for a fight.
Heh. You most certainly do not.
@BATTLE
Captain. I must log a complaint.
What is it, Cossack?
The refugees. How long must they remain aboard?
It won't be much longer.
How many are there?
Thirteen.
Thirteen? No. No. No. Nyet.
What is it?
They will bring us bad luck. I know this to be true.

Fields.MenuText: Don't tell me you're superstitious.
Without conceding your point - the sooner we're rid of them, the better.
They're our responsibility, at least for now.

Fields.DialogueText: Show me a successful sailor who isn't.
Agreed. They will bring nothing but trouble.
We will come to regret this.
What would you have me do in the meantime?
Keep careful watch. Thirteen is a bad number, Captain...
Ready, Cossack? The enemy is almost in range.
Da. I'd noticed.
I'm sure. But you don't look quite as... wildly enthused as usual.
Hrm.
I worry that the battles are not going as they should.
You worry too much, Cossack.
It is as I have feared. The refuges, the thirteen. They are bringing us bad luck.

Fields.MenuText: Don't be so superstitious.
Would you prefer if there were twelve or fourteen refugees?
Luck has nothing to do with our success in battle.

Fields.DialogueText: You think I'm being silly, don't you?
Please don't make fun, Captain.
No. But I believe it always helps.
What would you have me do?
We must get them off this ship safely as soon as possible.
*ALARM*
Agreed. But first let's worry about keeping ourselves safe.
@BATTLE
Captain, what are you reading?

Fields.MenuText: I noticed you speak it and wanted to learn more.
I think it's tactically important to help us fight the enemy.
I thought some of our non-Russian speaking crew members might be able to use it to better understand you.

Fields.DialogueText: ... I'm flattered.
That's a wise decision, Captain.
I do tend to ramble off in Russian from time to time, don't I?
Do you want to hear one of my favorite words in Russian?
Sure, Cossack. What is it?
Podsolnechnik.
Podsolnechnik?
Yes, that's it. It sounds bright and sunny, just like the word for sunflower should, don't you think?
Are sunflowers your favorite flowers, Cossack?
They are.

Fields.MenuText: How amusing.
I will keep that in mind.
I didn't take you for one to enjoy flowers.

Fields.DialogueText: Hmph. It's not so unusual.
... Whatever that means.
Oh, but I do.
My love for sunflowers is second only to my love of combat.
*ALARM*
Time to put that love into practice, Cossack.
@BATTLE
It's a book on the Russian language.
Cossack, are there any other Russian words you're especially enamored with?

Fields.MenuText: Of course.
You're a good teacher.
You're an odd one, Cossack.

Fields.DialogueText: Excellent.
Oh... why, thank you.
Oddities make things interesting, Captain.
Siniy.
Siniy... the word for blue.
That it is.
Why that particular word?
It is a color I enjoy. It reminds me of the ocean and the sky.

Fields.MenuText: It's my favorite color too.
Because you love adventure?
But you never wear blue.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not sure I believe you, Captain.
Absolutely. Blue is the color of freedom and adventure.
Because it clashes with my weaponry.
Fair enough.
*ALARM*
Do you suppose our enemy has a favorite color?
I do not care to find out.
@BATTLE
Ah, still interested in Cossack's school of Russian vocabulary, are you?
Kha! Vot oni idut!
Well said.
@BATTLE
Cossack, what was that I heard you murmuring during battle?
Hm? I think I said "here they come" in Russian at the start, but...
No, not that. Just before the first shot was fired.
I don't believe you heard anything, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: What was it? You can trust me.
Fair enough. I didn't mean to pry.
It sounded like a prayer.

Fields.DialogueText: If you must know, it was a prayer.
... It was a prayer. Sorry, I'm a little embarrassed.
It was.
I keep it, a written version of it, in the amulet around my neck.
What type of prayer is it? I'd like to hear it.
Perhaps another time, Captain.
Good news, Captain.
What's that?
I've spoken with another ship, and they've agreed to take the refugees off our hands.
You spoke with another Belle?
Yes, I'm in the process of building a small trade network.
They will take the refugees in exchange for extra blankets, soap, perhaps some fuel....

Fields.MenuText: No, the refugees are our responsibility. We see this to the end.
I can see this is very important to you.
Sorry. We can't spare any supplies.

Fields.DialogueText: *sigh* I admire your sense of duty, Captain.
Da. Thirteen is not a good omen.
Very well...
Have you noticed how difficult our battles have been recently?
Do you expect any battle to be easy?
Those refugees are bringing hardship down upon us.
*ALARM*
It looks like we're getting another chance to put your superstitions to the test.
@BATTLE
Captain. In all of this commotion, I have never gotten the chance to thank you.
For what?
You see, there is a great deal of persecution among the Cossacks...
Persecution?
My people are not treated well. I do recognize how fortunate I am to be here with you.

Fields.MenuText: You'll always be safe with me.
Well, the fleet is better with you on our side.
I'm sorry for the hardships your people have faced.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you for saying so, Captain.
I will do my best to serve.
We also know how to endure.
When is our next mission? I'm eager to prove myself further.
Relax. I'm willing to bet our next battle will come sooner than later.
@BATTLE
Cossack. You never did get to finish playing your song from before.

Fields.MenuText: If not now, when?
I'd really like to hear you play.
Don't tell me the great warrior is embarrassed.

Fields.DialogueText: Well... I suppose now is as good a time as any.
Well... if you insist.
Nonsense.
What shall I play?
Whatever you like.
I'm not sure I've ever seen a bandura played in person before, Cossack.
It's a traditional instrument of the Ukraine. I do love its tone.

Fields.MenuText: You play beautifully.
Sounds like you need more practice.
Such an exotic sound.

Fields.DialogueText: Why... thank you, Captain.
Hmph... what do you know of great music?
Yes, it is the sound of my homeland.
I'll teach you to play it sometime, if you like.
I think I would like that very much.
*ALARM*
Another time, obviously.
Well, yes.
@BATTLE
I don't really think now is the time, Captain.
Captain, I believe we have an opportunity.
What is it?
According to these reports, Morganas have been spotted transporting captured steel and ammunition in the area.
Well, that seems like something we want to stop.
If we take them by surprise, it should be an easy battle.
Nothing is ever easy where the Morganas are concerned.
You're right on that account. But I still have every confidence that we can win. And if we can salvage usable materials, all the better.

Fields.MenuText: It seems risky.
Set a course and prepare to attack.
We must gather more intel before we attack.

Fields.DialogueText: No victory is earned without risk, Captain.
Excellent.
Overly cautious as always, Captain.
@BATTLE
The consensus is that they're withdrawing out into open ocean to use it to repair and upgrade themselves.
Captain? Have you noticed...?
Those Morganas? Yes.
Morganas? Chert poberi! What did I say about bad luck, Captain?
Wait. There's a different issue?
Yes. But it can wait.
@BATTLE
Now. Captain, I really must speak with you.
I don't have time for more complaints about the refugees, Cossack.
The thirteen. They'll doom us all. But, no, that is not it, Captain.
Then what?
We have a stowaway.
A stowaway? Who?
Not who. What.

Fields.MenuText: Is this more of your superstitions?
Tell me more.
Are we in danger?

Fields.DialogueText: Danger is all around us, Captain.
My worst fears have come to pass...
Yes, Captain. Grave danger.
There is a... feline aboard the ship.
A cat?
*MEOW*
AAAHHH! Did you hear that?
... It's here.
it's just a cat, Cossack.
It's a terror.
*MEOW*
There it is again. I will find it and dispose of it!
Wonderful.
Morganas approaching, Captain.
We're ready for them.
Stick around on the bridge for a minute after the shooting stops. I have something I'd like to discuss with you.
Da. Of course.
@BATTLE
So. I've been checking out the state of our provisions, and it seems we've done an exceptional job of supplementing the official rations.
Plenty of food in the larder.
Great. I suppose now even that dreadful cat will be well fed.
I want to throw a feast for the refugees.
Why should they enjoy the spoils of victory? They have not been fighting.

Fields.MenuText: Have a heart, Cossack.
They are our guests.
You're welcome to join us, you know.

Fields.DialogueText: This is just more bad luck for us, Captain.
I suppose it does us no good to treat them poorly.
... You mean that?
Do you have a favorite meal? I can have the cooks prepare it.
I enjoy all types of foods... under one condition.
Name it.
I'd like it seasoned with lemon and dill if I could.

Fields.MenuText: Of course. Anything for you.
The more I learn about you, the stranger you become, Cossack.
Certainly. How about salmon?

Fields.DialogueText: Do not make me blush, Captain.
I have sophisticated tastes.
That would be perfect.
There is a rule, though. No weapons at the dinner table.
You are no fun, Captain.
Captain, there's an enemy blockade in our path.
So I've seen. What do you suggest we do about it?
Strike hard. Show them our true might.
That blockade is between us...
... And finally getting the refugees to safety.
Yes. But we need a plan.
Now is not the time for caution, Captain. The only way is to break through directly.

Fields.MenuText: You're right. Full steam ahead.
No. This calls for a careful approach.
Let's hope we survive this.

Fields.DialogueText: CHARGE!
Better to be a careful wolf than a reckless sheep.
We will fight until the end.
@BATTLE
Captain, requesting permission to undertake a new mission.
What type of mission?
Seek and destroy.
... You're talking about the cat, aren't you?
YES. I will seek out our feline interloper, and I will eliminate it.
I believe it sleeps on the deck.
Excellent. My mission will be completed swiftly.
Careful. That cat is more clever than you think.
Then it will make a worthy foe.
@BATTLE
I vote for "contain" rather than "eliminate," but knock yourself out.
Cossack, can I ask you a question?
Certainly, Captain.
What will you do? After the war is over?
After we have defeated the enemy?
I had not given it much thought until now.
We have whole lives to lead. There's more to do than fighting this war.
I suppose I would like to travel.

Fields.MenuText: Travel? Where to?
Aren't you doing that already?
Wouldn't you prefer to settle down somewhere?

Fields.DialogueText: Anywhere. Someplace new and exciting.
Navigating the fields of war is hardly travel.
I could never. I must be able to roam free.
I will bloom. No matter where I am planted.
Of that, I have no doubt.
@BATTLE
The attacks from the Morganas are happening more and more frequently.
Do you think it means something?
I suspect they are trying to exhaust us.

Fields.MenuText: I'm up for any fight if you are.
I'm not sure they're that coordinated. There may just be an inexhaustible number of them.
Are you growing weary of the fighting?

Fields.DialogueText: I'm honored to continue fighting by your side, Captain.
It doesn't matter. We will never quit, Captain.
The fight only invigorates me.
So, failure is not an option?
Nonsense, Captain. Failure is always an option.
It is the simplest available option at all times.
That's not very encouraging.
Failure is a choice, Captain. We can choose to fail or succeed.
I see.
What will you choose, Captain?
@BATTLE
Captain, I have not seen the feline for quite some time.

Fields.MenuText: That should make you happy.
Don't tell me you're worried about it.
You... didn't set any potentially lethal traps, did you?

Fields.DialogueText: It does...
Of course not...
I've done nothing to that awful creature. Yet.
But its absence concerns me. Perhaps it sensed something on the horizon.
Maybe it just sensed that you're hunting it.
Or maybe it sensed something worse. Like the Morganas.
It has to be on board somewhere.
I'm sure. But I cannot find it or sense it. For it to hide so well...
Finish your thought.
Something very dangerous must be headed our way, Captain.
@BATTLE
Be honest. You'll miss them when they're gone.
The refugees? The THIRTEEN? Not one bit, Captain.
Not even a little?
Thirteen less people aboard this ship will do wonders for our luck.

Fields.MenuText: Admit it, you like that we've helped them.
I suppose there's just no changing your mind.
It's taken more than luck to get us this far.

Fields.DialogueText: Were it up to me, we would have accepted a more exciting mission.
Not when it comes to bad luck, no.
Agreed. But a little more luck wouldn't hurt.
There's no way of telling how many more battles lie between us and safely delivering the refugees.
No matter, Captain. I'm ready.
@BATTLE
Captain, there are Morgana ships nearby.
Why aren't they attacking?
I'm not sure. They seem content to follow us.
Well, we're on a schedule, and I'm not thrilled about turning around to engage them. Can we outrun 'em?
And if that's what they're counting on?
You think they're driving us into a trap.
*ALARM*
I think we have our answer.
Very crafty. But we shall be craftier, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: Crafty? Careful Cossack, that almost sounds like strategy.
Yes, onward into battle.
I'd say this classifies as bad luck.

Fields.DialogueText: Perhaps you're rubbing off on me, Captain.
With the steel resolve of a warrior.
Today we will make our own luck.
@BATTLE
Almost there. Keep pushing.
The enemy is all around us, Captain.
We've gone too far to quit. We must get those refugees to safety.
We will, Captain. But we need a plan.
I never thought I'd hear you talk about a plan, Cossack.
I've come to find your methods... interesting, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: Any ideas?
Situations like this also call for some boldness and ferocity.
I'll take that as a compliment.

Fields.DialogueText: I think you can guess...
Ha! Now who's the headstrong one?
Don't get soft on me just yet.
We don't need to beat them all...
We just need to make an opening big enough for our ship to get through.
You read my mind, Captain.
Well, what are we waiting for? Let's be bold.
And smart.
@BATTLE
Captain, I thought you'd said we'd safely delivered the refugees.
We have.
Then why is that... that CAT still aboard the ship?
*MEOW*
It's still among us. We have to destroy it.

Fields.MenuText: Relax. It's just a cat.
Why are you so afraid of it?
I think I'll keep it around, to keep you in line.

Fields.DialogueText: JUST a cat? It is a devil.
It is bad luck. VERY bad.
You have a cruel sense of humor, Captain.
The only things worse than cats are owls.
... Owls?
Yes. Coba. Winged demons.
You think you might be overdramatizing the situation somewhat?
NO.
@BATTLE
I've come to a decision, Captain.
About the cat?
Yes. I... I think it's fine if it stays.

Fields.MenuText: Are you sure?
What changed your mind?
It's not too late to get rid of it.

Fields.DialogueText: No. But I can't seem to catch the cursed thing.
Nothing. I just think our attention is best spent elsewhere.
It's not worth the trouble.
What about it bringing bad luck?
Considering we've made it this far, I believe it brings a tolerable amount of bad luck.
Just admit it. You think it's cute.
... Well, it looks better than an owl.
Heh. If you say so.
And at least there are not thirteen felines.
@BATTLE
Hmm...
What are you doing?
Oh I was... I was praying.
For more success in battle?
No, something else... for our safety.
I thought you were most happy during battle.
No. It's just that... waiting makes me anxious.
Well, in the meantime, I got you something...

Fields.MenuText: A bell collar for the cat... so you can hear it coming.
A bouquet of podsolnukhi... sunflowers.

Fields.DialogueText: Good. It will be nice to know when bad luck is coming.
Captain I... they're beautiful. Thank you.
